items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
No further rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. 
We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 13/01/2025. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and please do not drive through floodwater, as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday evening, 12/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 12/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high but stable on the lower reaches of the river Churn. Flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 12/01/25, particularly in Cerney Wick.  It is forecast to remain dry today and into next week. We expect river levels to remain steady and begin a slow fall over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 13/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Lower River Cherwell. However, flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today, 12/01/2025, especially in the Thrupp areas. It is forecast to remain dry today and into next week. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 13/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  We continue to monitor the situation.  Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stable or dropping along the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, 12/01/25, especially in the Bourton On The Water and Newbridge areas.  It is forecast to remain dry today and into next week. We expect river levels to continue dropping slowly over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 13/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still falling steadily on the lower River Ray. However, the flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/01/2025, especially in the Islip areas.  It is forecast to remain dry om Sunday. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 13/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Nene has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are low on the upper reaches of the Thame and its smaller tributaries, and higher, but falling quickly on the downstream reaches.  Flooding of low lying land and roads is still expected to continue today, 12/01/2025, especially in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas.  It is forecast to remain dry on Sunday . Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 13/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are slowly falling but still remain high due to the previous rain and snowfall.  We are continually monitoring the situation and the river levels.
All areas between Ringwood and Christchurch could be affected and include all tributaries.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 13/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels continue to remain high. Flooding is possible  throughout the day 12/01/2025.    

This information is correct as of 07:30 on Sunday 12/01/2025. The causeway at Welney has approximately 30cm of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 25cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 

The Environment Agency is liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

The weather forecast is for no further rain for the next 5 days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself at risk. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 4pm today Sunday 12/01/2025.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River following recent heavy rain. Flooding may continue to affect locations near the Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, and Poyle Channel, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. No flooding to properties is expected. 

River levels remain high but have been slowly falling, and are expected to continue falling over the coming days. We are monitoring the situation closely. 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow morning, Monday 13th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but continue to fall at the Walcot River gauge following recent heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

No rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 12/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen but are now slowly starting to fall on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 11/01/25, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. The forecast for the next 24 hours is dry. River levels have peaked and are slowly falling but we expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
items.message:
River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no further rainfall for the next 5 days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   

No rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. 

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 12/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Saturday 11th January, and tomorrow, Sunday 12th January. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. It is likely that we may need to issue further flood alerts for this area over the weekend as levels remain high. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 12th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The Parrett, Yeo, Isle and tributary rivers rose as a result of the heavy rain last weekend.
Water has overtopped and and flooded the surrounding low-lying moors. Floodwater still persists. 
Minimal rainfall is forecasted for the weekend but this Flood Alert will potentially remain in force as we monitor rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels
Refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 12/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but falling slowly at the Tewks. Upper Pound, Mythe, Haw Bridge and Sandhurst gauges river gauges following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.   

Observed peaks: Mythe 4.38m Tuesday night, 07/01/2025, Haw Bridge 5.15m Thursday evening, 09/01/2025, Sandhurst 3.99m Friday morning, 10/01/2025, Gloucester 3.0m to 3.4m Friday afternoon, 10/01/2025.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 11am on Monday 13/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high and steady at the Bredon river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.   

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham and Twyning.   

Observed peaks: - Evesham 3.49m Tuesday morning, 07/01/2025; Bredon 3.4m Tuesday night, 07/01/2025.   

No further significant rainfall is forecast.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 11am on Monday 13/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
Flooding is still possible as the rivers in West Somerset remain high following heavy rainfall last weekend. However, water levels look stable and are slowly falling. 
Minimal rain is forecast for the weekend so there is only a small risk of further flooding this week, with this Flood Alert potentially remaining in force.
We are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 12/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
Floodwaters persist at Currymoor Reservoir following the significant rise of the River Tone caused by last weekend's heavy rainfall. There is now no flood warning for this area, only this flood alert, but we are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and flood assets.
Water enters via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River level exceeds 7.45m. Cutts Road floods as the Currymoor Drain level is above 5.75m, and New Road as the Drain level is above 6.18m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
Minimal rainfall is forecast this weekend, and while the catchments remain wet, any additional rain is expected to cause only a slight increase in water levels.
Pumping operations continue at Currymoor with all available pumps. Water levels are gradually receding and the Parrett Relief Channel is running.
Refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 12/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.    

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

Holderness Drain

items.message: This alert has been removed due to levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

River Thames from Mapledurham to Sonning
River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.description: River Thames from Shepperton to Molesey

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thames but have peaked and are slowly falling, as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 11/01/25, especially in the Molesey and Sunbury areas. The next 24 hours are forecast to be dry. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 12/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Datchet to Shepperton Green
Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar continue to fall steadily. In the last 24 hours the level at Alverstone has fallen by 0.1m. At Sandown, the river has fallen by 0.04m in the same time period. The weather is now mostly dry for the next 5 days. With virtually no rain forecast in that time, the river now has a good chance to recover. As water levels return to normal, any minor flood impacts should reduce significantly over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high and are expected to respond to recent rainfall, levels are likely to respond from the 8th of January onwards. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. 

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 14/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high but stable on the River Coln. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/01/25, particularly in the Fossebridge area. It is forecast to remain dry today and into next week. We expect river levels to start to fall slowly later today. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 13/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: Levels on the River Foulness and tributaries have continued to fall and are now below levels of concern. Water may remain on low lying land, and in flood storage areas and ings as water continues to drain away. We do not expect any significant rainfall over the next few days.

items.description: Lower River Witham
items.message: On Monday, we saw heavy rainfall in the Lower Witham catchment area. This means that the River Witham has risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the river to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is possible and therefore flood warnings have been issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 12/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include the Upper Hull area including Kilham, Nafferton, Driffield, Bainton, North Dalton, Leconfield, Leven, Brandesburton, North Frodingham and Beeford. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Sunday 12/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again in response to rainfall over the last week. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 14/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again in response to rainfall over the last week. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 14/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (69mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. During this time, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 30cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks in Old Alresford will be struggling to operate effectively. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday 08/01/2025 and Friday 10/01/2025, with up to 15mm expected on each day. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising slowly for around 2 weeks in response to this rain. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 14/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising very slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton following rainfall over recent weeks.

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue rising slowly over the coming week and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme and Burshill due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected around low-lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days.  Levels may fluctuate in response to the effects of the tide and our pumping operations, which are being operated to manage levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Sunday 12/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: On Monday we saw heavy rainfall in the Lower Witham catchment area. This means that the Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston have risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the rivers. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the rivers to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 12/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 3 days, over half a month’s rain (46mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level has increased by 0.5m. From Tuesday (07/01/2025), cellar flooding is expected at the southern end of the village at South End Close and the Dolphin Pub. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday (08/01/2025) and Friday (10/01/2025), with up to 35mm of rain possible across this period. Groundwater levels are expected to rise for around 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 13/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 3 days, over half a month’s rain (39mm) has been recorded at Andover. At Clanville Gate the rate of rise is fast at 11cm per day. From Tuesday (07/01/2025), it is possible that a small number of cellars may be affected in Appleshaw. Groundwater is affecting the sewer network at Penton Mewsey and the main road at Penton Grafton is flooded. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday (08/01/2025) and Friday (10/01/2025), with up to 35mm of rain possible across this period. Groundwater levels are expected to rise for around 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 13/01/2025.

items.description: Holderness Drain at Wawne Common and Woody Carr

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: This warning has been removed due to levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: River Trent at Girton
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold at the Carlton-on-Trent and Torksey river gauges. Properties are no longer at risk, but standing water remains in the village with access roads being affected. 
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to continue to fall throughout the day. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 16:00 today, 12/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  There is no further rainfall forecast.
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Trent at Collingham
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  There is no further rainfall forecast.
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Fossdyke Canal
items.message: On Monday we saw heavy rainfall in the Fossdyke Canal area. This means that the Fossdyke Canal has risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the river to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 12/01/25, or before if the situation changes.
